question: Ah, what'd you say, Pinback?
answer: Mafhkin oble groop...

question: Ah, what was that again, I still can't hear you?
answer: I said I'm trying to reach Talby. Something's wrong with the damn intercom. I need a last-minute diameter approximation.

question: Right, that checks out here.
answer: Pinback...

question: Yes, Doolittle.
answer: Your GHF reading is minus fifteen.

question: Doolittle...
answer: Yes.

question: I need a computer reading on a fail- safe mark.
answer: In a second.

question: Fail-safe locked. Ah, Sergeant Pinback call1ng Bomb #19. Do you read me, bomb?
answer: The bomb is suspended beneath the ship.

question: Well, bomb, we have about sixty seconds to drop. Just wondering if everything is all right. Have you checked your platinum euridium energy shielding? Swell. Let's synchronize detonation time. Do you know when you're supposed to go off? All right, I have detonation time at... Wait a minute, something's wrong with the clock. All right, I have detonation time at... no, that can't be right, it says three years. Okay, I have six minutes exactly. Does that check out down there? Arm yourself, bomb.
answer: Several lights blip on along the bomb's side.

question: Well... now what? What do, you have for us now. Boiler?
answer: Not much. Nothing at all in this sector.

question: Find me something, I don't care where it is.
answer: Well, I show a 95% probability of sentient life in the Horsehead Nebula...

question: Fuck that shit.
answer: Well, it is kind of a long shot...

question: It's a goddamn wild goose chase. Remember when Commander Powell found that 99 plus probability of sentient life in the Magellanic Cloud?
answer: Well, there's the possibility of...

question: Remember what we found? Fourteen light years for a fucking mindless vegetable that looked like a limp balloon and went squawk and let a fart when you touched it. Remember?
answer: All right, then...

question: So don't give me any of that sentient life crap. Find me something I can blow up.
answer: New star. Hey, guess what? I got a new star on the readout.

question: Which one?
answer: Another unknown. Not on the charts. A red dwarf.

question: Any planets?
answer: Yeah. Eight, it says here.

question: Any of 'em any good?
answer: Naah. All stable. What are you gonna name it?

question: What?
answer: The new star. What are you gonna name it?

question: Who cares. Don't bother me.
answer: Commander Powell would have named it.

question: Commander Powell is dead.
answer: Come on, Doolittle, give it a name.

question: Fred.
answer: Wha?

question: I hereby name this star Fred.
answer: Hey, Doolittle, here's one. An unstable planet. 85% probability of an unstable planet in the Veil Nebula that will probably go off its orbit and hit a star.

question: Sounds good. Chart a course for the Veil Nebula.
answer: Pinback, throw me the chart log.

question: Let's have some music in here, Boiler. Ship's log, entry number 1,943. Dark Star cruising at light speed through Sector Theta 990. En route to Veil Nebula for destruction of unstable planet. Our ETA is 1700 hours. Ship's systems continue to deteriorate... The short circuit in the rear seat panel which killed Commander Powell continues to be faulty. Uh... Storage Area 9... And because he's sitting next to it, it continues to bother Pinback. Storage Area 9 self-destructed last week, destroying entire ship's supply of toilet paper. That's all. Talby. Here's some breakfast. You know, Talby, you really ought to eat with the rest of us. You spend too much time up here.
answer: I like it up here.

question: Must get lonely being up here so much.
answer: I don't like to go below since Commander Powell died. I feel enclosed down there. If it were big enough, I'd sleep up here...

question: ... Should spend some time below, see more of the rest of the ship...
answer: ... You see, I can watch things up here, Doolittle. I love to watch things, just stare at the planets and meteors and asteroids, gas clusters...

question: You'll have plenty of time for that, you know. Figure it this way
answer: You know, Doollttle, if we're going into the Veil Nebula, we may actually find a strange and beautiful thing

question: Phoenix Asteroids? Never heard of 'em.
answer: They are a body of asteroids that make a complete circuit of the universe once every 12.3 trillion years. The Phoenix Asteroids... From what I've heard, Doolittle, they glow... glow with all the colors of the rainbow. Nobody knows why. They just glow as they drift around the universe. Imagine all the sights they've seen in the time they've been travelling -- the birth and death of stars, things we'll never see. The universe is alive, Doolittle. I thought it was all empty, but it isn't. In between the stars, it's seething with light and gasses and dust. There are little pebbles drifting around, planets no one on Earth has ever seen... No one but the Phoenix Asteroids...

question: You know what I think about, Talby?
answer: I'm getting something here, on this readout...

question: It's funny, but I kind of sit around, you know, a lot of time to myself...
answer: I think I'm getting a malfunction here somewhere.

question: I can't talk to the others, but with time to myself, I think about back home, back home at Malibu. I used to surf a lot, Talby. I used to be a great surfer.
answer: Lieutenant Doolittle, I'm getting a definite malfunction on one of the closed-circuit computer systems...

question: The waves at Malibu and Zuma were fantastic in the springs Talby. I can remember running out on the beach early spring mornings with my board and a wet suit...
answer: I can't seem to locate the malfunction exactly...

question: Waves would be peaking really high and glassy. Hit that water. Ridin' the wall just perfect.
answer: ... Somewhere in the autonomic relay circuits...

question: I guess I miss the waves and my board most of all.
answer: Ah, Doolittle, I do have a malfunction on this readout, but I can't seem to pinpoint exactly where it is.

question: Don't worry about it. We'll find out when it goes bad.
answer: I really think I should try and locate it immediately. Might be something important.

question: I'm getting this flickering light on one of my panels.
answer: What flickering light?

question: The one on unit... oh, I think it's GMR twelve zero zero.
answer: Oh. What's wrong now?

question: I'm not sure. I think something is fucked up somewhere in the ship, though.
answer: I hope it's not the oven again.

question: Yeah.
answer: Remember when the artificial gravity, went out in the toilet? Hey, Doolittle, think we'll ever find real intelligent life out there?

question: Sounds good, Talby. Let me know if anything important comes up.
answer: Why doesn't Talby ever eat down here with the rest of us?

question: He just likes it up in the dome, that's all.
answer: What's Talby's first name?

question: Ah, Lieutenant Doolittle? Sir?
answer: Sh, Talby, don't bother me now.

question: Ah, well, I think I've found the malfunction, sir. I'm in the Emergency Air Lock...
answer: Not now!

question: -- open circuit breakers --
answer: -- remove thrust drive repellant --

question: -- automatic channels open --
answer: -- Remark.

question: Only one thing to do. I'll have to ask Commander Powell. I'll have to ask him what to do. Commander Powell? Commander Powell, this is Doolittle. Can you read me?
answer: ... muffirup glurrinpinfropal...

question: Commander Powell, this is Doolittle. Ah, there's something serious come up, sir, and I have to ask you something.
answer: I'm glad you've come to talk with me, Doolittle. It's been so long since anyone has come to talk with me.

question: Commander, sir, we have a big problem. You see, the Veil Nebula bomb, Bomb Number 20, is stuck. It won't drop from the bomb bay. It refuses to listen and plans to detonate in -- -- less than eleven minutes.
answer: Doolittle, you must tell me one thing.

question: What's that, sir?
answer: Tell me, Doolittle, how are the Dodgers doing?

question: Well, sir, the Dodgers broke up, disbanded over thirteen years ago.
answer: Ah... pity, pity...

question: You don't understand, sir, we can't get the bomb to drop.
answer: Ah, so many malfunctions... why don't you have anything nice to tell me when you activate me? Oh, well, did you try the azimuth clutch?

question: Yes sir. Negative effect.
answer: What was that, Doolittle?

question: Negative effect.
answer: It didn't work?

question: That's correct, sir.
answer: Sorry, Doolittle. I've forgotten so much since I've been in here. So much.

question: What should we do, sir? The time is running out.
answer: Well, what you might try is --

question: Commander Powell? Commander, hello!
answer: Doolittle, hello?

question: Sorry, sir, you faded out there for a minute.
answer: Sorry.

question: What were you saying, Commander, about the bomb?
answer: Ah... it seems to me, Doolittle... Sorry, I've drawn a blank. Hold it. I'll have it again in a minute. I forget so many things in here, so many things. Hold on, just a minute, let me think...

question: Commander? Are you still there?
answer: Oh, yes, Doolittle, I'm thinking.

question: We're running out of time, sir.
answer: Oh, yes... Well, Doolittle, if you can't get it to drop you'll have to talk to it.

question: Sir?
answer: Talk to the bomb.

question: I already have, sir, and Pinback is talking to it now.
answer: No, no, Doolittle, you talk to it. Teach it Phenomenology, Doolittle.

question: Sir?
answer: Phenomenology...

question: The key!
answer: Key? Key? What is the key?

question: No, no, the key, the key to the fail-safe lock!
answer: Key?

question: Where's the fail-safe key?
answer: The key!

question: Where is it? What did you do with it?
answer: I don't have it. I don't know where it is.

question: Doolittle, are you there?
answer: I'm coming in now. I'm down by the Emergency Air Lock. Too much trouble to come in the Ventral Lock. Would you blow the seal on the emergency hatch so I can come in?

question: Oh, sure.
answer: Hello, Pinback, are you there?

question: Yeah, Doolittle. What's up?
answer: Talby was in the air lock. You blew him out of the ship. I'm going after him. Turn on his helmet radio so I can contact him.

question: Snap out of it, bomb.
answer: What the hell?

question: Yoo hoo, bomb...
answer: Bomb, hey bomb.

question: Whoa!
answer: Doolittle, Doolittle, where are you?

question: Here I am. I think I'm spinning... We're both falling, Talby, in opposite directions, away from each other. My -- my jetpack's gone.
answer: What happened, Doolittle?
